item.title: Not all cables are created equally
item.description: After a long time of planning, I finally ordered parts for a new PC last year. Black Friday seemed the best time to order, even though there were less deals than I’d have wanted. While waiting for my orders to be shipped, I also found out the availability numbers in the shops were a bit overstated. That might be worth a rant for itself, but sometimes one should just let bygones be bygones.

item.title: New year, old me
item.description: The year 2019 has gone just as 2020 came, ringing in the decade of the (hopefully) golden ’20s once again (see also: XKCD 2249). All the while I realized that I have shamefully neglected the blog I started on a whim, even though actually having several topic ideas to write about. I have no excuse, I’m just lazy like that. Getting from “Oh, I could write about that!” to an actual blog post that’s not just an incoherent string of thought fragments always seems like way too much of a pain in the rear department for the precious free minutes between Youtube, random web pages and my warm bed.

item.title: When a mail client isn't just a mail client
item.description: The case of Mailspring. Today, I was in need of a mail client for testing a server. I didn’t want to use my usual one, since that one is overloaded with accounts already. Installing one of the other big and well-known mail clients or -suites didn’t sound too appealing either. So I went to the search engine of my distrust, and keyed in “simple imap client linux”, in hopes of being presented with a list of small and simple IMAP mail clients.

item.title: More text processing for fun (and profit?)
item.description: Why, hello again. My last awkward post was but a single scratch on the surface of what awk can do. With this post, I will try to add a second one. The first example will involve a CSV file. CSV – comma-separated values – is a file type that presents values in a more or less tabular form, but instead of separated by spaces, they’re separated by commas. Who would’ve thought, huh?

item.title: Text processing for fun (and profit?)
item.description: Fasten your seatbelts, it’s going to get awkward. awk, together with grep, sed and fellows like tr, wc or cut are standard tools for command line text processing on Linux, BSD and other Unix-based operating systems. They’re also bread-and-butter tools for sysadmins. Can’t remember which config file a certain setting was in? grep for it. Someone wants to know how many requests the web server served yesterday? wc to the rescue!

item.title: Hello, World!
item.description: Hello, World! For some years now, I thought I should start a blog. Either because everyone and their grandma has one, or because I had exactly one more or less nonsensical idea I could’ve thrown out onto the internet. Being lazy as heck was the main deterrent of actually doing it, the other one was a mindset of having to do it “right” on first try. I’m not even sure what “right” means in the context of blogging, so those attempts didn’t last much longer.
